title: Deported with a credit card balance
question: I was deported last February, I keep paying my min. charge on my credit cards. I have about US.34.000.00 balance on all my credit cards. Do I have to pay for it? I lost my source of income and everything i owned in US because of the deportation issues. What should I do. i don't plan to go back to US anymore.
answers:
I will agree with the previous lawyer. It is rare they will come after you outside. However, if you are able to come back, it is a different story.



Good Luck

The creditor will probably do whatever it deems appropriate to obtain a judgment against you, because it is a relatively large balance. In fact, because you are out of the state, they may be able to argue that they can get a judgment against you for many years to come, because many states have a statute of limitations that does not expire when the debtor moves out of the state. However, if you cannot pay for it, why worry about it? I am not an immigration attorney, so I cannot give you any idea on whether this may affect your future application for reentry or a green card, but Homeland Security and the No Fly List do include review of all available data on a person, including their credit reports.

One thought is to negotiate with them. If they realize you have moved out of the country and know it will be really expensive to try and serve you outside the U.S., based on treaties the U.S. has for service on civil cases, they may be more willing to settle for much less than is owed. Also, your unemployed status means they know they will not get paid for many years. There is a ray of hope, if you can at least get this settled. Perhaps you can borrow a couple of thousand dollars or so and get the entire balance settled, so you don't need to worry about it.

If the creditor wants to come after you, it has to get a judgment in the United States, then find you in the world, then try to get its judgment recognized in that country and then try to collect. I doubt that will happen.
